title: Is there a way to get a proofreading service for free? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for the specific ask, but it’s a rather odd question to put to someone who makes a living editing. :-) You have to ask yourself, why would anyone offer a free proofreading service? If a stranger off the internet asked you to spend 15–20 hours of your life doing something for them, without any compensation for your time, what would your response be?There are plenty of proofreading services on the internet who say they will perform proofreading for next to nothing, certainly not even close to a minimum wage here in the West. You might get lucky, but generally, as with everything in life, you get what you pay for. Alternatively, there are some software packages that claim to pick up the most common errors with a varying degree of sophistication. Most of these also cost money, but many offer a free trial period. You could abuse the software developers’ generosity, sign up for a trial of software you never intend to purchase, proofread your text and then immediately cancel your subscription. I’m sure you wouldn’t be the first. This is what you pay people like me for. Yesterday I was proofreading a manuscript that contained the lines: “That anti-aircraft gun has been placed there by Artillery Command and it’s theirs to own, operate, and maintain. It can be as deadly for the gunners as it is for whoever is on the receiving end of the ordinance it fires.” If your proofreader is any good, or if the software is up to snuff, they might catch what’s wrong. If they don’t, they won’t, but you can bet some of your readers will, and leave you a scathing review on Amazon.

Richard makes a good point - professional editors do wonders, and they should always be rewarded for their time! I am trying to create a system that sort of a sharing economy type platform for proofreading/editing: r3ciprocity.com. I was inspired to create this system because there are so many people in need of help and there was not a clear place to find it. Actually, it goes back to the 2008 financial crisis, when some many of us had a hard time finding a job, and others needed help that could not afford it. I also wanted to create a system that could be based on reciprocity if you could not afford such services. Each time you edit someone else’s work, you get reciprocity credits that allows you to get your own work edited, with no system fees. Only if you want to eventually convert those credits to cash, does the system charge a fee. Of course, this is to ensure that I can pay for operations and future development. I was a graduate student for a very long-time, and I know how that feels. I really wanted some help with my own writing but could not afford it. Yes, you may not get a professional editor on the system - for those who are really in need, I would encourage you to find one elsewhere. However, from what I can tell, there are some really amazing people on the system that have edited some work for me. I am always impressed by the level of diligence and care of ordinary people - many sharing economy platforms have demonstrated this idea. At the moment, I figure this system is quite handy for those that need an ‘extra pair of eyes’ on your own writing. You can check out some very ‘authentic’ videos which I created here: What Is r3ciprocity.com All About? - YouTube Take care! :-)

Just a thought! But seriously, the more you invest in editing and proofreading, the better the results you get out of it. If you want free, then do it yourself. If you want good, then pay.
